IntroMergeInPlace
public class MergeInPlace extends Merge
Merge In Place Sort is a variant of the merge sort algorithm that performs the sorting operation directly on the input array, without using any additional arrays for merging. It achieves this by carefully manipulating the elements within the original array during the merging process.

  • Constructor Details

    • MergeInPlace

      public MergeInPlace()
      Merge In Place Sort:
      Is a variant of the merge sort algorithm that performs the sorting operation directly on the input array, without using any additional arrays for merging. It achieves this by carefully manipulating the elements within the original array during the merging process.

      Example:
      1. The algorithm recursively divides the array into smaller subarrays until each subarray contains only one element (considered sorted).
      2. Then, it starts merging the subarrays in pairs, using an in-place merging technique.
      3. To perform an in-place merge of two subarrays, the algorithm follows these steps:
      4. It compares the first element of the left subarray with the first element of the right subarray. If the left element is greater, it swaps the two elements.
      5. After the swap, it compares the new first element of the right subarray with the next element in the left subarray, and so on, until the elements in both subarrays are in the correct sorted order.
      6. Meanwhile, the elements in the left subarray are shifted one position to the right to make space for the swapped element from the right subarray.
      7. Once the merging of two subarrays is complete, the algorithm moves on to merge the next pair of subarrays, until the entire array is sorted.
      Note:
      Time Complexity of above approach is O(n^2 * log(n)) because merge is O(n^2). Time complexity of standard merge sort is less, O(n log(n)).

      Property:
      Worst Case Complexity: O(n^2)
      Best Case Complexity: O(n log(n))
      Average Case Complexity: O(n log(n))
      Auxiliary Space: O(n)
      Stability: Yes
      See Also:
      • IntroDPQMergeInPlace
      • IntroMergeInPlace

    • mergingInc

      public void mergingInc(Comparable[] array, int left, int mid, int right)
      mergingInc is a Java implementation of the merging step in the merge sort algorithm. It takes an array of Comparable objects, along with the indices representing the left, middle, and right boundaries of the subarray being merged.
      • The @SuppressWarnings("unchecked") annotation is used to suppress compiler warnings related to type safety when using the compareTo method.
      • The method starts by initializing the start variable to (mid + 1). This is the index where the second subarray begins.
      • The code then checks if the element at index mid is less than or equal to the element at index start. If this condition is true, it means that the two subarrays are already sorted, and there is no need to perform any merging. In that case, the method simply returns.
      • If the condition in step 3 is false, indicating that merging is necessary, a while loop is used to compare elements from both subarrays and merge them in sorted order.
      • Within the while loop, there is an if-else statement that compares the elements at indices left and start. If the element at left is less than or equal to the element at start, it means that the element at left is already in its correct sorted position, and we can simply move to the next element in the left subarray by incrementing the left variable.
      • If the element at left is greater than the element at start, it means that the element at start needs to be inserted into its correct position in the left subarray. The code creates a temporary variable value to store the value at index start, and an index variable index to keep track of the position where value will be inserted.
      • A while loop is used to shift the elements from index to left in the array one position to the right, effectively making space for value to be inserted at the correct position.
      • After shifting the elements, value is inserted at index left, and both left and start are incremented to move to the next elements in their respective subarrays.
      • The while loop continues until either the left subarray or the start subarray is exhausted, i.e., all elements from either subarray have been merged.
      mergingInc this method performs the merging of two sorted subarrays within the larger array. It uses a temporary variable to insert elements from the second subarray into their correct positions within the first subarray, effectively merging the two subarrays into a single sorted subarray.
      Parameters:
      array - to be arranged.
      left - from the array, index value, must be smaller than the mid and right value.
      mid - from the array, index value, must be smaller than the right value, and must be greater than the left.
      right - from the array, index value, must be greater than the left and mid value.

    • mergingDec

      public void mergingDec(Comparable[] array, int left, int mid, int right)
      mergingDec is a Java implementation of the merging step in the merge sort algorithm. It takes an array of Comparable objects, along with the indices representing the left, middle, and right boundaries of the subarray being merged.
      • The @SuppressWarnings("unchecked") annotation is used to suppress compiler warnings related to type safety when using the compareTo method.
      • The method starts by initializing the start variable to (mid + 1). This is the index where the second subarray begins.
      • The code then checks if the element at index mid is more than or equal to the element at index start. If this condition is true, it means that the two subarrays are already sorted, and there is no need to perform any merging. In that case, the method simply returns.
      • If the condition in step 3 is false, indicating that merging is necessary, a while loop is used to compare elements from both subarrays and merge them in sorted order.
      • Within the while loop, there is an if-else statement that compares the elements at indices left and start. If the element at left is more than or equal to the element at start, it means that the element at left is already in its correct sorted position, and we can simply move to the next element in the left subarray by decrementing the left variable.
      • If the element at left is smaller than the element at start, it means that the element at start needs to be inserted into its correct position in the left subarray. The code creates a temporary variable value to store the value at index start, and an index variable index to keep track of the position where value will be inserted.
      • A while loop is used to shift the elements from index to left in the array one position to the right, effectively making space for value to be inserted at the correct position.
      • After shifting the elements, value is inserted at index left, and both left and start are decremented to move to the next elements in their respective subarrays.
      • The while loop continues until either the left subarray or the start subarray is exhausted, i.e., all elements from either subarray have been merged.
      mergingDec this method performs the merging of two sorted subarrays within the larger array. It uses a temporary variable to insert elements from the second subarray into their correct positions within the first subarray, effectively merging the two subarrays into a single sorted subarray.
      Parameters:
      array - to be arranged.
      left - from the array, index value, must be smaller than the mid and right value.
      mid - from the array, index value, must be smaller than the right value, and must be greater than the left.
      right - from the array, index value, must be greater than the left and mid value.
